comments:
I clicked on "GenericScriptableView" which is shown in the spy when the Eclipse Monkey's Web view is shown.  Apparently, this leads to a NPE if you do not restart after installing Eclipse Monkey.

Steps:
1. Install Monkey using the update manager, but don't restart - instead, click "Apply Changes"
2. Scripts > Examples
3. Scripts > Views > Google Web View
4. Activate the new view
5. Alt-Shift-F1
6. Click on "GenericScriptableView".

I get the same NPE when using the spy in our RCP app. What is the expected behavior in RCP apps? In http://mea-bloga.blogspot.com/2007/09/spying-workingsets-log-view.html you (Chris) said, I'll get the fully qualified class name...
do you have the IDE plug-ins? If you have the IDE plug-ins (PDE/JDT) in your RCP application, then you will get the same behavior. If they aren't there, you will get a full classname.

I see same problem, but I'm working with "normal" Eclipse SDK.

The problem occurs, if the tagret platform (Eclipse 3.3) doesn't match the runtime platform of the selected component (for example, "error log" view from 3.4).

Steps to reproduce are much easier as described in comment 0:
1) Start Eclipse 3.4M3 SDK with fresh workspace targeting Eclipse 3.3 SDK
2) Open "Error log" view
3) Alt-Shift-F1 and click on the "LogView" class link
4) Enjoy new error log entry in the view ;-)

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.SearchablePluginsManager.addToJavaSearch(SearchablePluginsManager.java:271)
at org.eclipse.pde.internal.runtime.spy.SpyIDEUtil.openClass(SpyIDEUtil.java:43)
at org.eclipse.pde.internal.runtime.spy.SpyFormToolkit$SpyHyperlinkAdapter.linkActivated(SpyFormToolkit.java:46)

After switching target platform to the 3.4M3 anything works as expected.

moving to M4

yap, you're smart Andrei :)

The spy has a little limitation right now in regards to target platforms other than self. 

I'll try to tackle for M4, I appreciate the feedback and hope you find the tool useful.
targetting to M5, this one is slightly tough :o
